hotspots.label: Red Flowers
hotspots.fact: These beautiful red flowers show how plants use color to attract insects and animals that help them reproduce. The bright red color is a physical property of the petals that helps bees and other pollinators find the flowers. This is called **pigmentation** — that's the natural coloring in living things that comes from special substances in their cells.

vocabulary.definition: A characteristic of something that you can observe or measure without changing what it is, like color, size, or shape.

hotspots.label: Flower Stems
hotspots.fact: The green stems hold up the heavy flower heads against the force of gravity, which is a pulling force that brings objects down toward the ground. Plants have structures that help them support their own weight, just like your bones support your body! This is called **structure and function** — different parts of a plant do different jobs to help it survive.

vocabulary.definition: A force that pulls objects toward the Earth, making them fall down instead of floating up in the air.

hotspots.label: Clear Vase with Water
hotspots.fact: The water in the vase is a liquid that dissolves nutrients from the soil, which the flower stems absorb to keep the flowers alive and healthy. We can see through the clear vase because it's transparent — light passes right through it without being blocked. This is called **matter** — water is one of the three main states of matter that exists all around us.

vocabulary.definition: When something is clear and you can see right through it, like glass or clear plastic.

hotspots.label: Hanging Light
hotspots.fact: The light bulb above converts electrical energy into light energy, which helps us see the flowers clearly in the room. Light travels in straight lines and bounces off objects, allowing our eyes to see the beautiful red color of the flowers. This process is called **light reflection** — when light bounces off surfaces so we can observe them.

vocabulary.definition: The ability to make something happen or cause change, like electricity powering a light bulb to make it glow.
